awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum physics has the potential to expand computer power in industrially and economically significant ways. Just as computers have become an integral part of people's lives, quantum computation is likely to become equally impactful in the long term. The path to this grandiose goal needs achievable milestones along the way, and quantum simulation provides many such stepping stones.  However, to take advantage of quantum computation for simulating matter, new tools and methods must be developed to map model systems of fermions (e.g. electrons and certain nuclei) onto quantum computers. This project will develop models that incorporate topological ideas that aid qubit-based quantum computers to simulate the fermion systems found throughout chemistry, physics, and materials science. The nature of topologically inspired fermion-to-qubit mappings opens new possibilities for simulating electronic structure on the qubits of a quantum computer. This allows local addressing of information that is stored non-locally which helps to simplify the algorithms for quantum simulation.  The goals of this project include designing and implementing new algorithms that can be tested on early quantum hardware and incorporated into open-source code collections. The outcomes of this project will serve the broader scientific community by introducing tools that will be incorporated into rapidly developing quantum technology on the path to outpacing traditional computers. This project also include efforts to increase the inclusion of underrepresented groups in science and technology by inviting female freshmen and sophomore interns in conjunction with the Women In Science Project. 

As part of the long-term goal to understand how best to utilize a quantum computer, the Topological Fermionic Quantum Simulation project aims to flesh out topological quantum simulation algorithms. The central hypothesis of this work is that topological approaches can enhance the efficiency of quantum simulations. This hypothesis has been formulated based on this team's preliminary findings demonstrating benefits for fermionic encodings based on locality of the encoded spin operator. The proposed work has three major directions. The first delves into automation and implementation of the Bravyi-Kitaev Super-Fast model and explores its close connections to the toric code. The second area is to consider auxiliary fermion methods where additional modes are included to reduce the locality of the spin operators. Third, group theoretic approaches to black box simulation are ripe to explore and integrate with this growing area of quantum simulation. There are two cross-cutting themes that overlap with all branches of the project: local basis set design and benchmarking with numerical tools and with existing quantum hardware. The basis sets play a vital role in determining the efficiency and accuracy of any simulation while actual implementations provide metrics for success. Extension of quantum simulation algorithms based on topology has the potential for an immediate impact on the use of quantum computers. Additionally, this project opens questions about the nature of fermions, provides insights into the limitations of simulating them, and informs the requirements for the quantum simulation path to quantum supremacy.

This project is jointly funded by the Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics Experiment program in the Division of Physics and the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry (both Divisions are in the NSF Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences) as well as the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (NSF EPSCoR program).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF PROJECT OUTCOMES: "Topological Fermionic Quantum Simulation"

Computers have become an integral part of our lives, and quantum computation aims to reach similar levels of acceptance. To reach this goal, it is crucial to have achievable milestones. Quantum simulation serves as such a stepping stone. In this project, we explored quantum simulation algorithms inspired by topology to determine the best usage of a quantum computer.

We are pleased to share that we successfully covered all proposed areas including broader impacts. Our findings have been shared through publications, talks, and posters. Throughout this funding, we produced ten publications and three preprints, all acknowledging the grant. Moreover, we delivered over ten seminars and colloquia and presented several posters based on the results of this project. Below, we highlight our key findings under the NSF funding.


TOPOLOGICALLY NON-TRIVIAL SPIN-TO-FERMION TRANSFORMS

This area of research delved into the automation and implementation of the Bravyi-Kitaev Super Fast (BKSF) model. We considered the benefits of including auxiliary qubits to increase noise resilience and reduce the locality of the spin operators. Our initial publication generalized the original BKSF encoding for fermions: [K Setia, S Bravyi, A Mezzacapo, J Whitfield. Phys. Rev. Research 1, 033033 (2019)].  We showed that there are error-correcting properties of topological simulations of fermionic matter.

Our follow-up work in the next year [R Chien, J Whitfield. arXiv:2009.11860 (2020)] further extended the generalized super-fast transform. In our prior work, the fermion interaction graph reflected the structure of the spin interactions. With this work, we showed how nonlocal operators of traditional fermion-to-qubit encodings can be exchanged for local operators via a gauging procedure. This gauging procedure gave rise to an understanding of many known encodings that we called custom fermionic codes due to the connection to error-correcting codes.

We continued exploring the connection between topological fermionic simulation and error mitigation strategies. Our results were published in preprint: [R Chien, K Setia, X Bonet-Monroig, M Steudtner, J Whitfield. arXiv:2303.02270 (2023)]. There we described a new classical algorithm that we developed to simulate noisy quantum systems. For n physical qubits and k generators, (n − k) logical qubits can be modeled without noise. With our new algorithm, we can now simulate (n - k) qubits and still include certain types of noise with modest overhead.  Ultimately, our results showed that the fidelity under depolarizing noise can be significantly increased by going beyond the Jordan-Wigner transformation.


GROUP THEORY IN QUANTUM SIMULATION

The second project thread focused on group theoretic approaches to quantum simulation. Our first paper in this direction looked at Young frames in the context of quantum chemistry: [S Gulania, J Whitfield. arXiv:1904.10469 (2019)]. This paper serves as an entry point for exploiting knowledge of the permutation group in the quantum simulation context.

Further, we used molecular symmetries to reduce the qubit count required for quantum simulation of fermions [K Setia, R Chen, J Rice, A Mezzacapo, M Pistoia, J Whitfield. J. Chem. Theory Comput. 16, 10, 6091–6097 (2020)]. The method removes qubits corresponding to the identified symmetries from the molecular point group. The code for the project is open source and was incorporated into the Qiskit repository.


BASIS SET DESIGN

The third major area we researched was basis set design. We began with the Wilson phase space localized basis functions in publication: [J Brown, J Whitfield. J. Chem. Phys. 151, 064118 (2019)]. There, we considered the Wilson basis functions that are localized in both position and momentum.  We compared the Wilson basis against standard quantum chemistry basis sets as well as wavelets which are also localized in phase-space.  The techniques and numerical implementation help us study convergence to the continuum limit.

A second highlight in this area was the Quiqbox.jl library described in the paper [W Wang, J Whitfield. J. Chem. Theory Comput. 19, 22, 8032–8052 (2023)]. Quiqbox is a quantum chemistry and physics software that allows Gaussian basis set optimization for electronic structure problems. Our package introduces the concept of mixed-contracted Gaussian-type orbitals giving the flexibility to go beyond typical basis set frameworks such as atomic basis sets.


BROADER IMPACTS

This grant supported the research of two graduate PhD dissertations. Both degree recipients worked at quantum industry internships during the funding period. In addition to the graduate students, the Women In Science Project (WISP) at Dartmouth has enabled us to address the pipeline problems of female scientists. WISP allows freshmen and sophomore women to participate in research. During the funding period, PI Whitfield has supervised five WISP interns.

In early 2020, we piloted a one-week novice introduction to quantum computing at Hanover High School, employing Jupyter notebooks for educational purposes. Further, we co-organized the virtual 2020 Quantum Winter School, engaging over 100 students in lectures, programming exercises, and technical activities.
